content.story_intro: CISO criminally charged por cover-up de breach de 57M records

steps.title: El Breach: GitHub Credentials
steps.content: 2016: Attackers encontraron AWS credentials de Uber en GitHub public repo. Accedieron S3 bucket con 57M rider/driver records: names, emails, phone, license numbers.
steps.insight: Secrets in code = common mistake. GitHub scanning encontraría esto hoy.

steps.title: El Cover-Up: $100K 'Bug Bounty'
steps.content: CISO Joe Sullivan pagó $100K a attackers para destroy data y firmar NDA. Disfrazado como bug bounty. NO disclosure a reguladores (FTC) ni afectados. Obstruction of justice.
steps.insight: Cover-ups SIEMPRE se descubren. Legal obligation de disclosure en 48-72 hours (varies by jurisdiction).

steps.title: Criminal Charges
steps.content: 2020: DOJ acusó Sullivan de obstruction y misprision of felony. First CISO criminally charged. 2022: Encontrado guilty. Sentencia: 3 años probation, $50K fine.
steps.insight: CISOs tienen duty to disclose breaches. Cover-up = criminal liability. Ethics > job security.

steps.title: Lecciones: Incident Response
steps.content: Proper response: 1) Contain breach. 2) Forensics. 3) Notify regulators (GDPR 72h, varies by region). 4) Notify affected individuals. 5) Public statement. Transparency builds trust.
steps.insight: Sullivan case establece precedente: CISO liability es real. Ethics y compliance son non-negotiable.

back.definition: Birth → Joiner (hire) → Mover (role change) → Leaver (termination). Provisioning/de-provisioning automation. Reduce manual errors.
back.example: Hire: Auto-create accounts en AD, email, apps. Promotion: Update group memberships. Termination: Disable ALL access within 1 hour. HR system integration critical.

back.definition: Periodic review de access rights. Manager certifica: 'Does employee still need this access?'. Detect privilege creep, orphaned accounts.
back.example: Quarterly campaigns. SailPoint, Saviynt tools. Manager recibe list de subordinates' access. Certify or revoke. Compliance requirement (SOX).

back.definition: No single person controla end-to-end process. Prevents fraud. One person requests, otro approves. Finance: quien crea invoice ≠ quien paga.
back.example: Sarbanes-Oxley requirement. SAP: User NO puede create vendor y approve payment. Toxic combinations detected by IGA tools.

back.definition: GDPR, CCPA, HIPAA, etc. Right to be forgotten. Data minimization. Consent management. Breach notification (72 hours GDPR).
back.example: Uber: Failure to disclose within required timeframe = violation. GDPR fines up to 4% global revenue. Privacy by design.

unlock_content.title: Immediate Actions
points: Detect: SIEM alert, user report, third-party notification
Isolate: Segment compromised systems. Prevent lateral movement.
Preserve evidence: Don't destroy logs. Chain of custody for forensics.
Activate IR team: CISO, Legal, PR, Engineering
Document: Timestamped log of all actions taken
unlock_content.bonus_fact: First 24 hours critical. Containment speed reduces damage exponentially.

unlock_content.title: Forensics & Compliance
points: Forensics: Third-party firm (Mandiant, CrowdStrike). Determine scope, root cause.
Legal analysis: Which laws apply? GDPR (EU), CCPA (CA), HIPAA (health), etc.
Regulatory notification: GDPR 72h, state laws vary (CA 48h). Counsel advises.
Individual notification: Email affected users. Offer credit monitoring if PII.
Don't cover up: Uber lesson. Transparency > trying to hide.
unlock_content.bonus_fact: GDPR fines: British Airways £183M, Marriott £99M. Notification delay increases penalty.

unlock_content.title: Post-Incident
points: Eradication: Remove attacker presence. Patch vulnerabilities. Rotate credentials.
Recovery: Restore from clean backups. Gradual bring-up with monitoring.
Post-mortem: What went wrong? What went right? Blameless culture.
Remediation: Implement fixes. Update IR playbook.
Training: Share lessons company-wide. Improve defenses.
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Companies with tested IR plans recover 50% faster and 30% cheaper.

content.question: Uber CISO fue criminally charged porque:

options.feedback: Incorrecto. Breaches pasan. No es criminal tener breach. Lo criminal fue el cover-up.

options.text: Ocultó breach de reguladores, pagó attackers para firmar NDA, obstruyó investigación
options.feedback: CORRECTO! Joe Sullivan: 1) Sabía de breach (57M records). 2) NO notificó FTC (legal requirement). 3) Pagó $100K a attackers disfrazado como bug bounty. 4) Hizo firmar NDA a attackers. 5) Cuando FTC investigaba Uber, no reveló. Obstruction of justice. First CISO criminally prosecuted. Lesson: Transparency es mandatory, cover-up es criminal.
Incorrecto. Technical controls pueden tener gaps sin ser criminales. Cover-up ES criminal.
Incorrecto. Bug bounties son legítimos. Problema: esto NO era bug bounty real, era payoff para silence.
